III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Foster home record.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12328
Section (2) The record must contain all the following information:
Description
(e) Any written response from a foster parent, as provided by R
400.12327(6)(b).
Violation Potential Rule Violation.
Type
Allegation Foster parent is attempting to transfer their license to another
agency but has been rejected. The agencies that the foster parent
is attempting to transfer the license to are unable to see the foster
parent's written responses in the licensing file. Therefore, the
agencies evaluating the transfer are unable to see that the foster
parent disputes the findings in the previous special evaluations.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Parent: On 8/9/2024 I emailed Foster Parent as no
telephone number was indicated in the complaint. On 8/12/2024 I
interviewed Foster Parent about the complaint. She reported
being licensed with the agency since 2019 and having fostered
three siblings whom she had attempted to adopt and who were
removed from her care following a special evaluation alleging
inappropriate discipline, which she disputed. She affirmed
information as stated in the complaint and information reported by
Division of Child Welfare Licensing Supervisor (DCWLS) related
to the agency’s revocation recommendation, and the number of
past special evaluations. She said when the agency was
conducting special evaluations on her home she was submitting
statements. She said she found out the agency was not putting
her information in her file, such as a report from her therapist,
when the agency recommended a psychological and a statement
from her mother’s doctor related to a past investigation.
Additionally, there was an adoption reference she believes was
not placed in her file. She believes her efforts to transfer her
license to another agency has been hampered, because the
agency did not provide the agencies she sought to transfer to the
information she gave the agency in reply to the special
evaluations the agency completed on her. She believes she had
written a response to each special evaluation the agency
conducted on her. She did not advise how she had submitted
those written responses, nor the timeframe of them. I advised
Foster Parent the agency denied receiving responses from her
2

and that the department’s electronic file for her does not show any
response either. I informed her I had obtained a copy of the
documents she provided DCWLS, but those documents were not
responses to special evaluations. I asked whether she had copies
of the documents she had provided the agency, and or email
evidence showing when, and to whom, she provided those items
on 8/29/2024 via email.
Chief Administrator (CA): On 8/12/2024 CA responded to my
email contact to her about this complaint via email. CA indicated
Supervisor is the licensing supervisor who delt with Foster Parent
on all special investigations. CA indicated Foster Parent never
provided a written response to the agency on any special
evaluations.
Division of Child Welfare Supervisor (DCWLS): On 8/13/2024 I
interviewed DCWLS by TEAMS related to the complaint. DCWLS
reported it appeared that the agency had completed a number of
special investigations related to Foster Parent’s foster home that
were for the same allegations. She indicated the agency had
recommended revocation of Foster Parent’s foster home license
and that recommendation was not upheld by the department. She
said its alleged the agency never advised there was a
psychological report on Foster Parent. Nor that they had any
written responses from Foster Parent related to her special
evaluations. DCWLS said Foster Parent reported she completed
a psychological evaluation and provided that to the agency as well
as other written responses. Foster Parent reported after the
agency was not successful with the revocation of her foster home
license, she attempted to transfer her license and has not been
able to do so. Foster Parent expressed concern that her inability
to transfer her license is due to Catholic Charities not providing
her written responses to the special evaluations or all her
information to the other agencies she applied to transfer to.
DCWLS reported Foster Parent also expressed concern the
agency only shared the many special evaluations, which show her
negatively. The agency did not provide information like the
psychological evaluation she obtained. DCWLS provided me
documents Foster Parent had sent her copies of for my review.
Supervisor: On 8/19/2024 I interviewed Supervisor by telephone.
Supervisor reported being with the agency for 11 years. She
reported it was true that Foster Parent underwent a number of
special evaluations. Perhaps 13 over the course of Foster
Parent’s licensure with the agency. She reported it was corrected
that some of the evaluations were for the same allegations or
allegation type. All being around inappropriate discipline, and four
3

of the special evaluations led to the agency making a
recommendation to the department for revocation of Foster
Parent’s foster home license. She reported she completed a few
of Foster Parent’s past special evaluations and with others, she
was the supervisor. She said they always advised Foster Parent
that they could write a written response to the special evaluations
but Foster Parent never submitted a written respond to any of the
special evaluations.
Supervisor said the agency also completed an adoption home
assessment on Foster Parent, where the agency denied Foster
Parent’s application to adopt, and Foster Parent did not submit a
response related to that denial either. She said any written
response Foster Parent would have provided would have been
included/ uploaded into Foster Parent’s file. She reported the file
is electronic and there is nothing in a hard file. She said Foster
Parent did produce a letter from a psychologist who did not
complete a psychological evaluation on Foster Parent. She
reported that document was done because the agency’s adoption
department requested a psychological from Foster Parent related
to the adoption application. Supervisor reiterated that if there was
any document submitted by Foster Parent related to any special
evaluation, they would have included it in the special evaluation
file, which any licensed agency Foster Parent would have been
seeking to transfer to would have access to for review.
Supervisor reported Foster Parent has tried to transfer to four
separate agencies, and no one has accepted her. She said,
Foster Parent remains licensed through Catholic Charities.
Licensing Worker (LW): On 8/28/2024 I interviewed LW by
telephone. She affirmed information as reported by CA and
Supervisor. She reported completing about seven of Foster
Parent’s special evaluations dating back to 2021. She said Foster
Parent was always advised by letter of her rights to submit a
written response to the special evaluation. Foster Parent always
said she was going to write a response but never did so; not even
the last special evaluation where the agency had recommended
revocation. LW reported Foster Parent was aware of how to
submit documentations to her/the agency. She the agency
requested a psychological evaluation related to Foster Parents
adoption pursuit, not for licensing. Two documents were
completed; the one Foster Parent obtained on her own, which was
not sufficient, and one the agency recommended. Both are a part
of Foster Parent’s file.
4

LW advised given the departments electronic files the agency
does not send out foster parent documents when a foster parent is
seeking to transfer their license. They give courtesy access to the
agency that reaches out to them, so that agency can
access/review the foster parent’s CWLM file. LW said four
agencies, Agency 1, Agency 2, Agency 3, and Agency 4 reached
out and courtesy access was allowed each agency so that they
could review all documents/information in Foster Parent’s file and
make a decision about whether they would accept a transfer of
Foster Parent’s license.
Agency 3’s Licensing Supervisor(A3LS): On 8/29/2024 I spoke
with A3LS by telephone. She reported Catholic Charities gave her
access to Foster Parent’s licensing file, which she reviewed.
Foster Parent also sent them documents that were character
references. She said it had been a while since she reviewed the
file, but she recalls seeing a psychological report for Foster
Parent. She did not recall seeing any responses on file from
Foster Parent. Nor did she recall whether Foster Parent reported
providing any at that time.
Documents Reviewed:
Documents provided to me from DCWLS for Foster Parent which
showed:
• A lengthy letter from Foster Parent to the Michigan Children
Institute Superintendent explaining and or disputing what
she saw as flaws or incorrect information in /with her family
adoption assessment.
• A support letter from a past attorney who reported to have
served as GAL (Guadian Ad Litem) for three children who
had been in Foster Parent’s.
• A letter, not a psychological evaluation, from a licensed
professional counselor dated 4/16/2022. The letter
indicated the counselor met with Foster Parent for a
psychological on 4/13/2022. This document went on to
indicate the counselor’s professional opinion, of Foster
Parent based on his interview with her. He noted no
significant psychological or mental issues that would
negatively affect her mental, emotional, and physical ability
to be an adoptive parent.
• No letter or notes related to a response to any special
evaluations were included in the documents from DCWLS,
as provided by Foster Parent.
Foster Parent’s CWLM and MISACWIS file which showed:
5

• Nine special evaluations for Foster Parent that ranged from
2020 through 2023.
• Two psychological report documents as referenced by the
agency and Foster Parent.
• Corrective action plans for at least eight of the special
evaluations, with no note seen written on either corrective
action plan by Foster Parent.
• Closing letters/Documentation of written advisement to
Foster Parent from the agency related to her right to submit
a written response to the respective special evaluation.
• An Adoption Assessment completed for Foster Parent on
6/28/2022, which denied Foster Parent’s application and
referenced three reference letters submitted by Foster
Parent along with the psychological document already
referenced in this report, and an Adult Psychological
Evaluation from a counseling agency.
• Documentation of courtesy access being granted to a
representative from Agency 1, Agency 2, Agency 3 and
Agency 4.
A copy of a 5/2/2022 screen shot of an email from Foster Parent
to CA, Supervisor and LW to show she submitted a copy of her
psychological report.
Six typed letters signed by Foster Parent which she reported she
had submitted to the agency:
• Two were not dated and referenced a special evaluation
being initiated on 5/20/2020 and 12/16/2020 respectively.
• Two others were dated. One referenced a special
evaluation initiated on 5/20/2020, which Foster Parent
dated her signature for 9/13/2020. The second for a
special evaluation started on 9/9/2021, which Foster Parent
dated her signature for 12/20/2021.
• Two did not relate to a special evaluation. One related to
something to do with a winery visit and was dated 1/2/2021.
Another related to staff allegedly entering her home without
her permission and was dated 12/20/2021.
Email responses from CA, Supervisor, and LW on 10/24/2024
related to copies of documents from/referenced by Foster Parent,
as to whether they had seen or received these documents that
Foster Parent indicated she had provided the agency in response
to past special evaluations. CA acknowledged information being
documented related to a doctors note with respect to Foster
Parent’s mother and the psychological note/letter from Foster
6

Parent. She, as well as Supervisor and LW denied ever seeing the
other documents that reportedly pertained to special evaluations.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documents reviewed the
evidence does not support the allegations. Nor that the agency did
not include documents from the foster parent in the foster parent’s
licensing file.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
